Literature Review: Retinal degeneration, encompassing both inherited and age-related conditions, represents a significant cause of irreversible vision loss worldwide. The retina's limited capacity for self-repair has spurred interest in stem cell-based regenerative therapies as a potential avenue for restoring vision. This literature review explores the factors influencing the efficacy of stem cell-based approaches in treating retinal degeneration, focusing on cell delivery, the immunological microenvironment, and the integration of transplanted cells with host retinal circuitry. The advent of human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) has revolutionized the field, offering a renewable source of retinal cells for transplantation. Three-dimensional (3D) retinal organoid cultures have further advanced the field by providing a model that closely recapitulates human retinal development in vitro, enabling the generation of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), photoreceptors, and ganglion cells for therapeutic use. However, several challenges remain in translating these advances into effective treatments. Cell delivery methods must ensure the survival, integration, and functionality of transplanted cells within the hostile environment of the degenerating retina. The recipient's immunological microenvironment plays a critical role in the success of cell transplantation, with immune rejection posing a significant barrier. Strategies to modulate the immune response, including the use of immunosuppressive drugs and the engineering of hypoimmunogenic stem cells, are under investigation. Furthermore, achieving functional connectivity between transplanted cells and the host retinal circuitry, both locally and with central brain areas, is essential for restoring vision. Advances in understanding the molecular cues guiding synaptic integration and the development of bioengineered scaffolds to support cell alignment and connectivity are promising. Despite these challenges, stem cell-based therapies hold immense potential for treating retinal degeneration. Continued research into optimizing cell delivery, modulating the immune response, and enhancing synaptic integration will be crucial for realizing this potential. The integration of stem cell biology, immunology, and bioengineering approaches offers a multidisciplinary pathway towards developing effective regenerative therapies for retinal degeneration.
